elements.content: Uranyl peroxide compounds are important to the nuclear fuel cycle and are typically formed from the direct addition of hydrogen peroxide or through photochemical pathways that utilize a sacrificial solvent. In this study, we explore the use of THF as a peroxide forming solvent that could be used to promote the crystallization of uranyl peroxide materials. Compound 1 (Li­(H2O)2(UO2)­(C7H3NO4)­(C4H5NO4)·2H2O) was originally crystallized after aging for 10 days at room temperature and was characterized by X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, Raman spectroscopy, and UV/vis spectroscopy. Exposure to ambient light for one month led to the complete transformation of 1 to compound 2 ((C5NH6)2[(UO2)2(μ-O2)­(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]·4H2O). Oxidation of the THF molecule was proposed as the major mechanism for the formation of the secondary uranyl peroxide compound, which was accelerated in the presence of the UO2 2+ cation and light. Presence of THF hydrogen peroxide was confirmed by spectral (NMR and Raman) analysis of the mother liquor. Compound 3 ((C4N2H12)­[(UO2)2(μ-O2)­(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]·2.75H2O) formed in the presence of transition metal cations and additional experiments indicated that photoexcitation was not necessary to create free peroxide in this system. Autoxidation of the THF molecule is the most likely mechanism for peroxide formation and indicates that judicial choice of solvent can lead to the formation of new uranyl peroxide materials.

elements.content:
Autoxidation of THF as a cosolvent in the synthesis can enhance the formation of uranyl peroxide materials.

Introduction

Uranyl peroxide complexes and related materials were largely ignored by the actinide chemistry community until their relevance to the nuclear fuel cycle began to emerge almost 20 years ago. Detailed investigations for this system began with the structural characterization of the mineral, studtite [(UO2)­(O2)­(H2O)2]·2H2O, which is the only known naturally occurring peroxide phase. Thermodynamic investigations indicate that surprisingly low concentrations of H2O2 (1.1 × 10–14 M) can induce the formation of studtite on the surface of uranium dioxide and that the mineral is stable over geologic time scales. Studtite could have been dismissed as a rare mineral phase, but it was concurrently identified as a major alteration product on the surface of spent nuclear fuel in contact with water for 1.5 years. Uranyl peroxide solids have also been identified to exist within yellowcake formed during the initial stage of production, solidifying their importance throughout the entire fuel cycle.

Introduction

Uranyl peroxide complexes and related materials were largely ignored by the actinide chemistry community until their relevance to the nuclear fuel cycle began to emerge almost 20 years ago. Detailed investigations for this system began with the structural characterization of the mineral, studtite [(UO2)(O2)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O, which is the only known naturally occurring peroxide phase. Thermodynamic investigations indicate that surprisingly low concentrations of H2O2 (1.1 × 10-14 M) can induce the formation of studtite on the surface of uranium dioxide and that the mineral is stable over geologic time scales. Studtite could have been dismissed as a rare mineral phase, but it was concurrently identified as a major alteration product on the surface of spent nuclear fuel in contact with water for 1.5 years. Uranyl peroxide solids have also been identified to exist within yellowcake formed during the initial stage of production, solidifying their importance throughout the entire fuel cycle.

elements.content: Studtite was the only uranyl peroxide phase of interest until the Burns research discovered the first uranyl peroxide nanoclusters in 2005, which ultimately resulted in a cascade of novel compounds with unique structural topologies. The first reported uranyl nanocluster contained 24, 28, and 32 uranyl cations linked through peroxide or hydroxide bridges to form nanoscale capsules with fullerene-like topologies. Since this original discovery, a large family of uranyl peroxide compounds has been crystallized that range from single monomeric species to clusters containing 124 U6+ atoms. The topological variations within these nanoclusters are due to the formation of four-, five-, six-, and eight-membered rings built from [UO2(O2)­(OH)2]4– or [UO2(O2)3]4– units. Presence of other bridging ligands, including pyrophosphate and oxalate, results in additional structural diversity and the formation of core–shell structures. Counterions in solution, particularly alkali- and alkali-earth cations, also impart controls on the structural topologies and stability of individual clusters in solution. Initial discovery of these clusters focused on their unique chemistry, but additional studies found that these soluble uranyl peroxide phases may be important to the nuclear fuel cycle because they enhance the corrosion of UO2 solids placed in alkaline solutions or seawater. The robustness and prevalence of the uranyl peroxide nanocapsules in solution has also inspired cluster-based separations technologies and nanoscale compositional tuning for fuel fabrication processes.
elements.clean_text: Studtite was the only uranyl peroxide phase of interest until the Burns research discovered the first uranyl peroxide nanoclusters in 2005, which ultimately resulted in a cascade of novel compounds with unique structural topologies. The first reported uranyl nanocluster contained 24, 28, and 32 uranyl cations linked through peroxide or hydroxide bridges to form nanoscale capsules with fullerene-like topologies. Since this original discovery, a large family of uranyl peroxide compounds has been crystallized that range from single monomeric species to clusters containing 124 U6+ atoms. The topological variations within these nanoclusters are due to the formation of four-, five-, six-, and eight-membered rings built from [UO2(O2)(OH)2]4- or [UO2(O2)3]4- units. Presence of other bridging ligands, including pyrophosphate and oxalate, results in additional structural diversity and the formation of core-shell structures. Counterions in solution, particularly alkali- and alkali-earth cations, also impart controls on the structural topologies and stability of individual clusters in solution. Initial discovery of these clusters focused on their unique chemistry, but additional studies found that these soluble uranyl peroxide phases may be important to the nuclear fuel cycle because they enhance the corrosion of UO2 solids placed in alkaline solutions or seawater. The robustness and prevalence of the uranyl peroxide nanocapsules in solution has also inspired cluster-based separations technologies and nanoscale compositional tuning for fuel fabrication processes.

elements.content: Synthetic uranyl peroxide phases are generally created through the direct addition of hydrogen peroxide to the system, but there are alternative chemical and physical pathways that generate peroxide in situ. The uranyl peroxide clusters and synthetic studtite are formed through the addition of 30% hydrogen peroxide to aqueous solution in the presence of varying amounts of base and counterions. Formation of uranyl peroxide within ore bodies or on the surface of spent nuclear fuel requires the generation of peroxide in situ; thus, a number of other mechanisms have been investigated and reported in the literature. Hydrothermal treatment of uranyl solutions in the presence of organic ligands produces peroxide phases, although the reported yields for the solid compounds are low. Photocatalysis can also generate uranyl peroxide materials in the presence of an organic substrate. During this process, the organic ligands or cosolvents are used as a substrate by which excited U­(VI)­O2 2+ cation abstracts a hydrogen atom to create a radical. These radicals react with the O2 gas present in the solution to create O2 – in situ and bind with soluble U­(VI)­O2 2+ cations in solution to create uranyl peroxide complexes. This photocatalytic process may occur even after the formation of uranyl hydrolysis products, as previously described for both uranylpyridine and pyrrolidone systems. More recently, a uranyl peroxide phase was also identified by Kirkegaard et al. in hydrated uranyl fluoride solids, and experiments in the absence of light suggested a nonphotocatalytic mechanism. Nonphotocatalytic pathways have been proposed in previous studies as Kubatko et al. postulated that naturally occurring studtite forms through the alpha-radiolysis of water. Interaction between water molecules and ionizing radiation leads to the creation of H, O, and OH radicals that can form peroxide in situ. The uranyl fluoride system explored by Kirkegaard et al. used depleted uranium; thus, the radiation-levels and time scale do not align with peroxide generation through alpha-radiolysis. This recent study indicates that additional mechanisms for in situ peroxide generation have not yet been delineated and have implications in the solid-state transformation of uranyl compounds and the formation of novel materials.

elements.content: During our synthetic efforts to develop novel metal–organic compounds, we discovered the complete transformation of a uranyl carboxylate coordination polymer (1; (Li­(H2O)2(UO2)­(C7H3NO4)­(C4H5NO4)·2H2O) into a uranyl peroxide coordination complex (2; (C5NH6)2[(UO2)2(μ-O2)­(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]·4H2O) in the presence of light. Additional experiments in a related system revealed that a similar uranyl peroxide coordination complex (3; (C4N2H12)­[(UO2)2(μ-O2)­(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]·2.75H2O) could be formed in the absence of light. Herein, we describe the synthesis and chemical characterization of these uranyl peroxide materials and probe the mechanism of peroxide generation within this system. We propose that catalytic in situ peroxide generation from the cosolvent may be a new mechanism for peroxide formation and could be used in future efforts to design novel uranyl peroxide materials.

elements.content: All solutions were prepared using Millipore water (18.2 MΩ·cm), and chemicals purchased were used directly without further purification. Caution: (UO 2 )­(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O contains radioactive 238 U, which is an α emitter, and, like all radioactive materials, must be handled with care. These experiments were conducted by trained personnel in a licensed research facility with special precautions taken toward the handling, monitoring, and disposal of radioactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

Synthesis

All solutions were prepared using Millipore water (18.2 MΩ⋅cm), and chemicals purchased were used directly without further purification. Caution: (UO  2  )(NO  3  )  2  ⋅6H  2  O contains radioactive 238 U, which is an α emitter, and, like all radioactive materials, must be handled with care. These experiments were conducted by trained personnel in a licensed research facility with special precautions taken toward the handling, monitoring, and disposal of radioactive materials.

elements.content: A 0.2 M stock solution of 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate was generated by adding 0.334 g of the acid form of the ligand to 10.0 mL of water. Base (1.0 M LiOH) was added to deprotonate the carboxylate groups and promote dissolution. A 1.0 mL aliquot of the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate stock solution was combined with 1.0 mL of a 0.2 M uranyl nitrate (Flynn Scientific, Inc.) solution in a 20 mL glass scintillation vial. THF (2.0 mL) was also added to the vial, and then the solution was thoroughly mixed. A 1.0 mL aliquot of a 0.2 M iminodiacetic acid solution was subsequently added and the pH adjusted to 4.4 using pyridine. The solution was also layered with 5.0 mL of acetonitrile to aid in crystallization. After approximately 10 days, yellow acircular single crystals were formed with 75% yield based upon U. Crystals remaining in the mother liquor for a period of 1–2 months changed color from yellow to orange (2; (C5NH6)2[(UO2)2(μ-O2)­(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]·4H2O) and formed in similar yields. Initial syntheses were performed on the benchtop in the presence of ambient light (benchtop and sunlight), and a portion of subsequent experiments was stored in a drawer to minimize photochemical reactions.

Li(H2O)2(UO2)(C7H3NO4)(C4H5NO4)⋅2H2O (1)

A 0.2 M stock solution of 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate was generated by adding 0.334 g of the acid form of the ligand to 10.0 mL of water. Base (1.0 M LiOH) was added to deprotonate the carboxylate groups and promote dissolution. A 1.0 mL aliquot of the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate stock solution was combined with 1.0 mL of a 0.2 M uranyl nitrate (Flynn Scientific, Inc.) solution in a 20 mL glass scintillation vial. THF (2.0 mL) was also added to the vial, and then the solution was thoroughly mixed. A 1.0 mL aliquot of a 0.2 M iminodiacetic acid solution was subsequently added and the pH adjusted to 4.4 using pyridine. The solution was also layered with 5.0 mL of acetonitrile to aid in crystallization. After approximately 10 days, yellow acircular single crystals were formed with 75% yield based upon U. Crystals remaining in the mother liquor for a period of 1-2 months changed color from yellow to orange (2; (C5NH6)2[(UO2)2(μ-O2)(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]⋅4H2O) and formed in similar yields. Initial syntheses were performed on the benchtop in the presence of ambient light (benchtop and sunlight), and a portion of subsequent experiments was stored in a drawer to minimize photochemical reactions.

elements.content: A 0.2 M stock solution 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylic acid (2,6-PDC; Sigma-Aldrich) was prepared by adding 0.3342 g of 2,6-PDC to 10.0 mL of water and dissolved in solution using a 1.0 M piperazine solution. A 1.0 mL aliquot of the 2,6-PDC solution was added to a scintillation vial and mixed with 0.5 mL of a 0.2 M solution containing a metal salt (NiCl2, CoCl2, Zn­(NO3)2, La­(NO3)3, Al­(NO3)3, and CrCl3). Uranyl nitrate (0.5 mL of 0.2 M solution) and 3.0 mL of THF were added to the solution and thoroughly homogenized using a vortex mixer. Vials were covered with perforated parafilm and allowed to slowly evaporate at room temperature. After approximately 2 weeks, small, orange-yellow plates were formed in 30% yield based upon U. Experimental conditions were also varied in this synthesis. Light levels were changed by storing the vials in a different location (benchtop or drawer) and solvents (acetonitrile, ethyl ether, and DMSO) were varied. Peroxide formation conditions were also tested by separately adding 0.25 mL of FeCl2 and lowering the pH to 2.

(C4N2H12)[(UO2)2(μ-O2)(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]⋅2.75H2O (3)

A 0.2 M stock solution 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylic acid (2,6-PDC; Sigma-Aldrich) was prepared by adding 0.3342 g of 2,6-PDC to 10.0 mL of water and dissolved in solution using a 1.0 M piperazine solution. A 1.0 mL aliquot of the 2,6-PDC solution was added to a scintillation vial and mixed with 0.5 mL of a 0.2 M solution containing a metal salt (NiCl2, CoCl2, Zn(NO3)2, La(NO3)3, Al(NO3)3, and CrCl3). Uranyl nitrate (0.5 mL of 0.2 M solution) and 3.0 mL of THF were added to the solution and thoroughly homogenized using a vortex mixer. Vials were covered with perforated parafilm and allowed to slowly evaporate at room temperature. After approximately 2 weeks, small, orange-yellow plates were formed in 30% yield based upon U. Experimental conditions were also varied in this synthesis. Light levels were changed by storing the vials in a different location (benchtop or drawer) and solvents (acetonitrile, ethyl ether, and DMSO) were varied. Peroxide formation conditions were also tested by separately adding 0.25 mL of FeCl2 and lowering the pH to 2.

elements.content: High-quality single crystals were isolated from the mother liquor, coated in Infinium oil, and mounted on a Nonius Kappa CCD single-crystal X-ray diffractometer equipped with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å) and a low-temperature cryostat. Data were collected at 100 K with the Nonius Collect software package, and peak intensities were corrected for Lorentz, polarization, and background effects using the Bruker APEX II software. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the program SADABS, and the structure solution was determined by intrinsic phasing methods and refined on the basis of F2 for all unique data using the SHELXTL version 5 series of programs. U atoms were located by direct methods, and the O, N, and C atom positions were identified in the difference Fourier maps calculated following refinement of the partial-structure models. Hydrogen atom positions associated with the organic molecules were fixed using a riding model. provides select crystallographic parameters for compounds 1–3. Intermolecular π–π stacking distances and angles within the crystal structures were analyzed using the Mercury software. Additional information on bond lengths and angles can be found in Table S1 in the Supporting Information section, and the crystallographic information files can be found on the Cambridge Structural Database by requesting numbers 1880171–1880173.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Experiments

High-quality single crystals were isolated from the mother liquor, coated in Infinium oil, and mounted on a Nonius Kappa CCD single-crystal X-ray diffractometer equipped with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å) and a low-temperature cryostat. Data were collected at 100 K with the Nonius Collect software package, and peak intensities were corrected for Lorentz, polarization, and background effects using the Bruker APEX II software. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the program SADABS, and the structure solution was determined by intrinsic phasing methods and refined on the basis of F2 for all unique data using the SHELXTL version 5 series of programs. U atoms were located by direct methods, and the O, N, and C atom positions were identified in the difference Fourier maps calculated following refinement of the partial-structure models. Hydrogen atom positions associated with the organic molecules were fixed using a riding model.  provides select crystallographic parameters for compounds 1-3. Intermolecular π-π stacking distances and angles within the crystal structures were analyzed using the Mercury software. Additional information on bond lengths and angles can be found in Table S1 in the Supporting Information section, and the crystallographic information files can be found on the Cambridge Structural Database by requesting numbers 1880171-1880173.

The purity of the bulk materials was confirmed using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments. Briefly, the samples were prepared by grinding the crystalline samples using a mortar and pestle under acetone and deposited on zero background Si wafer. Diffractograms were collected from 5 to 60° 2θ with a step size of 0.02 and a count time of 1 s/step on a Bruker D-8 ADVANCE diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation and a LynxEye solid state detector.
elements.clean_text:
Chemical Characterization of Solid Phase

The purity of the bulk materials was confirmed using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments. Briefly, the samples were prepared by grinding the crystalline samples using a mortar and pestle under acetone and deposited on zero background Si wafer. Diffractograms were collected from 5 to 60° 2θ with a step size of 0.02 and a count time of 1 s/step on a Bruker D-8 ADVANCE diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation and a LynxEye solid state detector.

elements.content: Raman spectra were collected on all compounds using a Thermo Nicolet Almega XR High-Performance Dispersive Raman Spectrometer equipped with a 785 nm laser. Several high-quality crystals were selected from the sample, and unit cell parameters of the single-crystals were collected to confirm the identity of the material. The selected crystals were secured on a glass slide using double-sided tape, and spectra were recorded from 90 to 3470 cm–1 using an acquisition time of 32 s.

elements.content: Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra were collected on Agilent Cary 5000 UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer. Crystals were ground in a mortar and pestle and packed in the solid-state sample holder. Spectra were collected from 200 to 800 nm at intervals of 1 nm and a 600 nm min–1 scan rate. The raw diffuse reflectance data was converted to absorbance using the Kubelka–Munk function.

The raw diffuse reflectance data was converted to absorbance using the Kubelka-Munk function.

elements.content: Formation of peroxide in solution was explored for a range of conditions and characterized using spectroscopic methods. The mother liquor from fresh and aged synthetic experiments were characterized using Raman and NMR (1H and 13C) spectroscopy. NMR spectra were collected on a 500 MHz Bruker AVANCE spectrometer using the Topspin 2.1 software. Solution Raman was collected on each sample using a SnRI high-resolution Sierra 2.0 Raman spectrometer equipped with a 785 nm laser. Data on each sample was collected in multiacquisition mode and averaged for analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Phase Investigations

Formation of peroxide in solution was explored for a range of conditions and characterized using spectroscopic methods. The mother liquor from fresh and aged synthetic experiments were characterized using Raman and NMR (1H and 13C) spectroscopy. NMR spectra were collected on a 500 MHz Bruker AVANCE spectrometer using the Topspin 2.1 software. Solution Raman was collected on each sample using a SnRI high-resolution Sierra 2.0 Raman spectrometer equipped with a 785 nm laser. Data on each sample was collected in multiacquisition mode and averaged for analysis.

elements.content: Yellow acircular crystals (1) were initially noted in the vial containing the uranyl cation in the presence of 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate and iminodiacetate ligands. Structural characterization of the solid-state compound indicated that each U6+ cation bonds with two O atoms to form the nearly linear uranyl moiety at UO distances of 1.785(2) and 1.790(2) Å. One 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate ligand is chelated to the U6+ metal center about the equatorial plane in a tridentate fashion and two IDA molecules coordinate through monodentate linkage to O atoms on the terminal carboxylate groups (a). This leads to an overall coordination number of seven and results in the formation of a uranyl pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Equatorial U–O bond lengths for 1 range from 2.320(2) to 2.371(2) Å, and the U–N distance is 2.522(2) Å. Iminodiacetate molecules also bridge neighboring uranyl polyhedra to create a corrugated one-dimensional chain structure along the (101) plane (b). Additional intermolecular interactions occur between the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate molecules located on the adjacent chains, as the centroid to centroid and the centroid offset distances between aromatic rings are 3.75 and 3.68 Å, respectively. These distances are consistent with π–π interactions occurring between the aromatic rings of the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate molecule with a parallel displaced geometry. Free carboxylate O atoms on the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate ligand further coordinate to Li+ cations located between the uranyl chains. Tetrahedral geometry about the Li+ cation is completed with additional bonds to two ligated water molecules with Li–O bond distances ranging from 1.896(6) to 1.951(6) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Initial Formation of Compound 1 

Yellow acircular crystals (1) were initially noted in the vial containing the uranyl cation in the presence of 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate and iminodiacetate ligands. Structural characterization of the solid-state compound indicated that each U6+ cation bonds with two O atoms to form the nearly linear uranyl moiety at UO distances of 1.785(2) and 1.790(2) Å. One 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate ligand is chelated to the U6+ metal center about the equatorial plane in a tridentate fashion and two IDA molecules coordinate through monodentate linkage to O atoms on the terminal carboxylate groups (a). This leads to an overall coordination number of seven and results in the formation of a uranyl pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Equatorial U-O bond lengths for 1 range from 2.320(2) to 2.371(2) Å, and the U-N distance is 2.522(2) Å. Iminodiacetate molecules also bridge neighboring uranyl polyhedra to create a corrugated one-dimensional chain structure along the (101) plane (b). Additional intermolecular interactions occur between the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate molecules located on the adjacent chains, as the centroid to centroid and the centroid offset distances between aromatic rings are 3.75 and 3.68 Å, respectively. These distances are consistent with π-π interactions occurring between the aromatic rings of the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate molecule with a parallel displaced geometry. Free carboxylate O atoms on the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate ligand further coordinate to Li+ cations located between the uranyl chains. Tetrahedral geometry about the Li+ cation is completed with additional bonds to two ligated water molecules with Li-O bond distances ranging from 1.896(6) to 1.951(6) Å.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit for compound 1 is shown as thermal ellipsoids (50%). Yellow, red, light blue, black, and orange ellipsoids represent U, O, N, C, and Li atoms. (b) Uranyl polyhedra are linked into a corrugated chain through the iminodiacetate linkers. U6+ coordination is depicted a yellow polyhedra, and the organic ligands are shown as wire representation. The H atoms in both images have not been shown for clarity.

elements.content: Further characterization of compound 1 indicated the formation of a monophasic solid and exhibited spectroscopic signals that are typically observed for a uranyl carboxylate materials. The PXRD pattern of the bulk compound (Figure S4) matched with the predicted pattern obtained from the structural characterization, indicating that the bulk material is phase pure. This was further confirmed by elemental analysis of the solid material (Table S2). Raman spectrum of 1 contains a major band at 833 cm–1 that corresponds to the uranyl symmetric stretch (v 1). Additional peaks present in the spectra are indicative of the presence of both the 2,6-PDC and iminodiacetate ligands (see Table S3 in the Supporting Information section for additional band assignments). The absorption spectrum for 1 contains a broad band from 200 to 360 nm that corresponds to the π–π* transition of the 2,6-PDC molecule. A second band spanning 350 to 500 nm can be assigned to the ligand to metal charge transfer band associated with the U6+ cation. Fine vibronic features are also noted within the spectra and are similar to those reported for other uranyl compounds.

elements.content: When compound 1 remains undisturbed in the mother liquor, the crystals transform to a secondary uranyl peroxide phase. Compound 1 forms yellow acircular crystals (a), and over the course of one month on the benchtop, orange, blocky crystals begin to form in the solution (b). Within approximately two months (c), 1 is completely transformed to the secondary phase (2). The newly formed orange crystals were analyzed with single crystal X-ray diffraction, revealing the formation of a discrete uranyl peroxide dimer (d). In this compound, the 2,6-PDC molecules remain chelated to the U6+ metal centers in a tridentate fashion, but the iminodiactetate molecule is not observed within the solid-state material. Uranyl cations are bridged by an μ–η2,η2-peroxide molecule, and two ligated water molecules also coordinate through the equatorial plane in the trans-position. Uranyl (UO) bond lengths observed between 1.775(3) and 1.781(3) Å, which is within range of the original compound 1. Equatorial bonds ranging from 2.332(2) to 2.466(2) Å for U–O and U–N distances are observed at 2.567(3) and 2.591(3) Å. The overall molecular formula for the dimer observed within 2 is [(UO2)2O2(H2O)2(2,6-PDC)2]2– and charge-balancing pyridinium cations are located within the extended crystalline lattice. Neighboring uranyl dimers engage in additional π–π interactions with centroid to centroid distances of 3.833 Å between adjacent aromatic groups.
elements.clean_text:
Photochemical Transformation of 1 to 2 

When compound 1 remains undisturbed in the mother liquor, the crystals transform to a secondary uranyl peroxide phase. Compound 1 forms yellow acircular crystals (a), and over the course of one month on the benchtop, orange, blocky crystals begin to form in the solution (b). Within approximately two months (c), 1 is completely transformed to the secondary phase (2). The newly formed orange crystals were analyzed with single crystal X-ray diffraction, revealing the formation of a discrete uranyl peroxide dimer (d). In this compound, the 2,6-PDC molecules remain chelated to the U6+ metal centers in a tridentate fashion, but the iminodiactetate molecule is not observed within the solid-state material. Uranyl cations are bridged by an μ-η2,η2-peroxide molecule, and two ligated water molecules also coordinate through the equatorial plane in the trans-position. Uranyl (UO) bond lengths observed between 1.775(3) and 1.781(3) Å, which is within range of the original compound 1. Equatorial bonds ranging from 2.332(2) to 2.466(2) Å for U-O and U-N distances are observed at 2.567(3) and 2.591(3) Å. The overall molecular formula for the dimer observed within 2 is [(UO2)2O2(H2O)2(2,6-PDC)2]2- and charge-balancing pyridinium cations are located within the extended crystalline lattice. Neighboring uranyl dimers engage in additional π-π interactions with centroid to centroid distances of 3.833 Å between adjacent aromatic groups.

elements.content: Representative images showing (a) crystals of 1 formed after 10 days of aging; (b) crystals of 1 transforming to compound 2 crystals after two additional weeks of storage in the mother liquor; and (c) complete transformation of compound 1 to the 2 crystals after additional aging. (d) Thermal ellipsoidal representation of compound 2 at 50% probability. U, C, O, N, and H are depicted as yellow, black, red, blue, and pink spheres, respectively.

(d) Thermal ellipsoidal representation of compound 2 at 50% probability. U, C, O, N, and H are depicted as yellow, black, red, blue, and pink spheres, respectively.

elements.content: The major structural changes observed in the phototransformation of compound 1 to compound 2 include the formation of the peroxide, loss of chelating ligand, and change in charge-balancing counterion. Formation of 2 requires the removal of the IDA ligand before the addition of the μ2-O2 bridge, and currently, it is unclear if the IDA is removed before or during the process. It is very likely the that formation of the [(UO2)2O2(H2O)2(2,6-PDC)2]2– complex results in dissolution of compound 1, followed by reprecipitation of 2. This is supported by the change in morphology that is observed in the crystalline material () and the presence of a different counterion (Li+ vs C5H6N+). Therefore, this phototransformation not only requires in situ generation of peroxide but additional acid–base reactions to occur in solution.

elements.content: This dimeric species observed in 2 has previously been reported by Masci and Thuery using a different synthetic procedure. In this previous study, the compound was synthesized by adding uranyl nitrate to 2,6-PDC, camphoric acid, and triethylamine in boiling methanol. After cooling, Masci and Thuery reported a few crystals formed upon standing, suggesting a very low yield of the overall product. The resulting material did not contain the camphoric acid, but triethylamine was present in the crystalline lattice and participating in H-bonding interactions with the ligated water molecules, free carboxylate O atoms, and the bridging peroxide units. Bond distances reported by Masci and Thuery are within error of those observed for 2, but the difference in the charge balancing cation (triethylamine vspyridinium) leads to different crystalline packing and unit cell parameters.

elements.content: PXRD of the material that remained in the mother liquor for two months was matched to the predicted pattern obtained from the structural characterization of compound 2 (Figure S5) indicating the complete transformation of the initial material in yields of 70% (based upon total U). The uranyl symmetric stretching band in the Raman spectrum of 2 is similar (835 cm–1) to 1, which is reasonable given that the uranyl bond distances are within error for these two phases (Figure S7). Bands associated with the 2,6-PDC ligand are still observed within the spectrum, but a new peak at 869 cm–1 is now observed corresponding to the O–O stretch of the peroxide molecule. The absorption spectrum of 2 (Figure S8) contains a π–π* transition associated with 2,6-PDC molecule, but it is blue-shifted compared to compound 1. In addition, the LMCT band of the uranyl has also blue-shifted, and the vibronic features within this region are less apparent.

elements.content: We confirmed that crystals of 2 formed through a photochemical reaction by systematically varying the light exposure to compound 1 (). The reaction was repeated under several different light conditions: ambient light on the benchtop, direct sunlight in the windowsill, and absence of light within a closed drawer. The reaction on the laboratory bench consistently resulted in the transformation from 1 to the secondary material (2). Rapid transformation (several days) also occurred on the windowsill and resulted in the precipitation of an amorphous material. Crystals that formed within the closed laboratory drawers remained as stable crystals of 1 over the course of the two-month experiment. As an additional variable, 1.0 mL of 30% H2O2 was also added to one of the vials that were placed into the dark drawer. Initially, the addition of hydrogen peroxide resulted in the complete dissolution of 1, but 2 begins to appear in the solution after several months of slow evaporation.

elements.content: The commonly accepted mechanism for the in situ generation of peroxide typically involves photoexcitation of the uranyl moiety. Bacak et al. proposed a light-driven mechanism in which UO2 2+ ions undergo photoexcitation with 423 nm light to form *UO2 2+. Excited species can be quenched in the presence of organic or inorganic substrates, and the *UO2 2+ is reduced to UO2 +. The substrate forms a radical species by hydrogen abstraction, which in turn reacts with molecular oxygen to form oxidized substrate products and peroxide anions. UO2 + ions also react with molecular oxygen and oxidize back to its original UO2 2+ state while also reducing molecular oxygen to peroxide. These peroxide anions readily bind with the uranyl ions and form stable uranium peroxide species. This photoexcitation process has been utilized to degrade organic molecules as demonstrated by Xia et al. and Yang et al., where both groups utilized uranyl coordination polymers as a photocatalyst for the oxidation of Rhodamine B dye.

Excited species can be quenched in the presence of organic or inorganic substrates, and the *UO2 2+ is reduced to UO2 +. The substrate forms a radical species by hydrogen abstraction, which in turn reacts with molecular oxygen to form oxidized substrate products and peroxide anions. UO2 + ions also react with molecular oxygen and oxidize back to its original UO2 2+ state while also reducing molecular oxygen to peroxide. These peroxide anions readily bind with the uranyl ions and form stable uranium peroxide species. This photoexcitation process has been utilized to degrade organic molecules as demonstrated by Xia et al. and Yang et al., where both groups utilized uranyl coordination polymers as a photocatalyst for the oxidation of Rhodamine B dye.

elements.content: While several studies documented the in situ generation of peroxide, Thangavelu and Cahill provided a detailed investigation of mechanism and identity of the substrate. This study utilized both ambient light and direct sunlight to generate peroxide in methanol, which resulted in the formation of three compounds containing uranyl peroxide dimers chelated by acetate or N-donor ligands. Attempts to synthesize these materials in dark, using solvothermal methods, in the absence of O2, or by direct addition of H2O2 were not successful. NMR spectroscopy was utilized to further explore the identity of the organic substrate that was photodegraded by the U6+ cation in this process. Thangavelu and Cahill reported the presence of both aldehyde and carboxylic acid protons in the NMR spectrum and observed similar peaks in the direct oxidation of methanol by hydrogen peroxide. This provided convincing evidence that methanol was the substrate consumed in the hydrogen abstraction process.

Attempts to synthesize these materials in dark, using solvothermal methods, in the absence of O2, or by direct addition of H2O2 were not successful. NMR spectroscopy was utilized to further explore the identity of the organic substrate that was photodegraded by the U6+ cation in this process. Thangavelu and Cahill reported the presence of both aldehyde and carboxylic acid protons in the NMR spectrum and observed similar peaks in the direct oxidation of methanol by hydrogen peroxide. elements.content: The near-complete transformation of compound 1 to 2 is also rather remarkable because of a large amount of peroxide is generated in situ. Most of the previous studies regarding in situ peroxide generation did not provide experimental yields or indicated that formation of the final product was low. The exception to this was in the case of the uranyl mercaptopyrimidine system in ethanol, which reported yields of 40–45%. Compound 2 forms in 70% yield, which is almost double that of previous methods that report in situ generation. If one considers that 2 has a U/peroxide ratio of 2:1, then at least 2.4 mg of peroxide was produced in situ on the benchtop. This is likely the lower range for in situ generation of peroxide because (1) even the 25% of U6+ remaining in solution could be complexed to peroxide; and (2) previous syntheses of uranyl peroxide materials require excess peroxide for the formation of the solid-state materials.

elements.content: One possible route for the formation of larger amounts of peroxide could be related to the identity of the solvent (or the substrate) used during the synthesis of compound 1. THF was used as a cosolvent to aid in the crystallization process, and as part of the ether family, it is a known peroxide former. Ethers will react with dissolved O2 gas through autoxidation to form unstable peroxide. describes how THF could act as the substrate for the uranyl radical and is based upon a previously reported mechanism for autoxidation of this solvent. In this case, the photoexcited uranyl cation can initiate the autoxidation process by abstraction of the alpha hydrogen to the oxygen to create the tetrahydrofuran-2-yl radical (1). This intermediate form will react with dissolved O2 gas to form the peroxy radical through a coupling reaction (2). At this point, a uranyl species present in solution could react with the peroxy radical to form the uranyl peroxide species (3). Alternatively, additional hydrogen abstraction with a second THF molecule could occur to form the hydroperoxide form and a second THF radical (3). This hydroperoxide could also interact with the uranyl to form a complexed peroxide species (4) and return the THF molecule to its original form. This process is different than the photocatalytic degradation mechanism proposed previously by Bakac and others because in the original mechanism the substrate is oxidized and consumed during the process. Instead, multiple radical species THF species are involved and can provide readily available peroxide for the formation of the uranyl species.
elements.clean_text: One possible route for the formation of larger amounts of peroxide could be related to the identity of the solvent (or the substrate) used during the synthesis of compound 1. THF was used as a cosolvent to aid in the crystallization process, and as part of the ether family, it is a known peroxide former. Ethers will react with dissolved O2 gas through autoxidation to form unstable peroxide.  describes how THF could act as the substrate for the uranyl radical and is based upon a previously reported mechanism for autoxidation of this solvent. In this case, the photoexcited uranyl cation can initiate the autoxidation process by abstraction of the alpha hydrogen to the oxygen to create the tetrahydrofuran-2-yl radical (1). This intermediate form will react with dissolved O2 gas to form the peroxy radical through a coupling reaction (2). At this point, a uranyl species present in solution could react with the peroxy radical to form the uranyl peroxide species (3). Alternatively, additional hydrogen abstraction with a second THF molecule could occur to form the hydroperoxide form and a second THF radical (3). This hydroperoxide could also interact with the uranyl to form a complexed peroxide species (4) and return the THF molecule to its original form. This process is different than the photocatalytic degradation mechanism proposed previously by Bakac and others because in the original mechanism the substrate is oxidized and consumed during the process. Instead, multiple radical species THF species are involved and can provide readily available peroxide for the formation of the uranyl species.

elements.clean_text: 1  Proposed Photocatalytic Cycle To Form Peroxide in the Presence of THF

elements.content: THF undergoes autoxidation in the presence of oxygen, but the amount of peroxide formed in this system suggests that uranium plays a role in enhancing this reaction. Howard and Ingold measured the rate of autoxidation of 0.78 × 103 M–1/2 s–1/2, and Yasuda reported that THF forms peroxide in concentrations of 500 ppm after exposure to ambient O2 levels for one month. Considering only 2 mL of THF was used in this experiment, the previous reports suggest that autoxidation could contribute 1 mg of O2. Thus, photocatalysis in the presence of UO2 2+ enhances peroxide formation and increases the yield of compound 2.

elements.content: In an attempt to validate our proposed mechanism and gain insight into the peroxide generation in this system, we characterized the solution phase using Raman and 13C NMR spectroscopy. Raman spectra of the initial solution (Figure S9) shows evidence of THF in solution, with a major band at 913 cm–1 (ring breathing mode) and medium to weak peaks at 1484, 1451 (CH2 deformation), 1240 (CH2 wag), and 1027 (ring stretch) cm–1. The shoulder on the major band occurs when the solvent is a THF water mixture and is caused by H-bonding interactions between the two molecules. After complete conversion to 2, the Raman spectra of the solution changes significantly. The major band shifts to 926 cm–1, and a peak appears at 384 cm–1 (). This blue shift in the ring breathing mode has previously been shown to arise upon formation of a THF hydroperoxide molecule and occurs along with an appearance of an in-plane ring deformation at 416 cm–1. The band at 384 cm–1 is red-shifted from the previously reported THF hydroperoxide species, which may suggest additional interactions with residual uranyl complexes in solution. A 13C NMR spectrum was also collected for the mother liquor after complete conversion to compound 2 (Figure S10). Peaks at 1.50 and 118 ppm correspond to acetonitrile, and the peaks at 25 and 67 ppm are typically assigned to THF. The small peak at 107 ppm has been linked to the THF hydroperoxide species or more specifically to the carbon directly connected to the peroxide functional group. Both spectroscopic techniques provide additional evidence to support the formation of the peroxide in this system to form from the THF cosolvent.

elements.content: Unlike the study by Thangavelu and Cahill, the 13C NMR did not provide evidence of THF degradation products, such as formate acetal, γ-butyrolactone, or other lactone species. This suggests that the process is either catalytic in nature and/or the THF hydroperoxide molecule is stabilized in solution. An additional point to note is that THF sold commercially will often contain a peroxide inhibitor, such as butylated hydroxytoluene, at levels between 100 and 300 ppm. Butylated hydroxytoluene acts as a radical scavenger, destroying peroxide that builds up in the THF solvent. However, U6+ binds strongly to peroxide and may effectively prevent scavengers from destroying the radical. This would permit the formation of uranyl peroxide materials even in the presence of a peroxide inhibitor.

elements.content: This study suggests solvents that can be considered peroxide formers would be candidates for large-scale in situ generation of peroxides and provide additional insights to previous studies, such as the formation of a uranyl peroxide dimer reported by McGrail et al. In this system, diethyl ether is used as a cosolvent and is a well-known peroxide former. Unlike THF, diethyl ether does not require the presence of gaseous O2 to create peroxide. Instead, UV activation of diethyl ether results in homolytic scission of the C–H bond resulting in the formation of a 1- or 2-ethyloxethyl radical. These radicals are quite reactive and will participate in additional hydrogen abstraction reactions with either the bridging hydroxide groups or molecular water (the U6+ source was uranyl nitrate hexahydrate) to form peroxides. Photoexcitation of diethyl ether would also result in the release of H2 gas, which was also observed in the previous study. This suggests an alternative mechanism to the direct activation of the bridging μ2-OH groups for in situ generation of the peroxide in nonaqueous systems.

elements.content: As we explored the possibility of doping transition metals into uranyl metal−organic material, we also discovered an alternative synthetic method to create uranyl peroxide dimers. The U6+ and transition metal cations (Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Al3+, and La3+) were combined with the 2,6-PDC ligand and produced yellow-orange color crystals after slow evaporation of the mother liquor (water and THF in a 2:3 vol/vol ratio). Structural characterization of the resulting crystals indicated the formation of a uranyl peroxide dimer (compound 3). The identity and coordination mode of the ligands are identical to the dimeric species observed in 2, but in this case, the ligated water molecules are located on the same side to form the “cis” conformation (), whereas compound 2 can be considered the “trans” confirmation. The UO bond distances are observed at 1.776(7) and 1.777(7) Å, with equatorial U–O and U–N distances at 2.344(8)–2.440(17) Å and 2.575(8) Å, respectively. Additional π–π interactions between the coordination complexes resulted in the formation of the extended solid with an overall formula of (C4N2H12)­(UO2)2(μ-O2)­(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2·2.75 H2O. The centroid to centroid distance of the pyridine rings is 3.55 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Formation of the Compound 3: Pure Autoxidation of THF To Form Peroxide in Situ 

As we explored the possibility of doping transition metals into uranyl metal-organic material, we also discovered an alternative synthetic method to create uranyl peroxide dimers. The U6+ and transition metal cations (Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Al3+, and La3+) were combined with the 2,6-PDC ligand and produced yellow-orange color crystals after slow evaporation of the mother liquor (water and THF in a 2:3 vol/vol ratio). Structural characterization of the resulting crystals indicated the formation of a uranyl peroxide dimer (compound 3). The identity and coordination mode of the ligands are identical to the dimeric species observed in 2, but in this case, the ligated water molecules are located on the same side to form the "cis" conformation (), whereas compound 2 can be considered the "trans" confirmation. The UO bond distances are observed at 1.776(7) and 1.777(7) Å, with equatorial U-O and U-N distances at 2.344(8)-2.440(17) Å and 2.575(8) Å, respectively. Additional π-π interactions between the coordination complexes resulted in the formation of the extended solid with an overall formula of (C4N2H12)(UO2)2(μ-O2)(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2⋅2.75 H2O. The centroid to centroid distance of the pyridine rings is 3.55 Å.

elements.content: Analysis of the powder X-ray diffractogram of the material indicated that the bulk phase was pure (Figure S6), and additional chemical characterization was performed on the material. Major bands in the Raman spectra were similar to that observed with 2, with the ν1 symmetric stretch of the uranyl present at 838 cm–1 and the peroxide band observed at 869 cm–1 (Figure S7). Additional bands between 600 and 700 and 1000–1100 cm–1 are associated with ring bending and breathing modes of the 2,6 pyridine dicarboxylate molecule, respectively. The absorption spectrum of 3 is again similar to compound 2 in that both the π–π * transition and the U6+ LMCT band are blue-shifted compared to that of 1 (Figure S8).

elements.content: Initially, compound 3 was synthesized by slow-evaporation on the benchtop, suggesting that again the mechanism could be linked to a photochemical reaction, but additional synthetic parameters were varied to further explore the system (). First, crystals of 3 only occur in the presence of Co2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Al3+, and La3+ ions and do not form when Fe2+ or Cr3+ cations are present. Varying the uranyl to transition metal ratio also altered the formation of the product. Crystals of 3 can only be formed with the UO2 2+/M n+ ratio is 1:1 and excess of either the uranyl cation or the transition metal cations will prohibit the formation of this compound. Removal of the transition metal but keeping all other synthetic conditions constant results in the formation of the UO2(C7H3NO4)­(H2O) compound previously reported by Harrowfield et al. Compound 3 is formed in the presence of ambient light, but they also form without photoactivation of the uranyl cation (slow evaporation in a closed drawer under the lab bench). Additional experiments were also performed to alter the possibility of free peroxide in the system. Ferrous ion (0.25 mL of 0.2 M solution) was added to the reaction to consume free peroxide (through the oxidation to ferric iron), and crystals were unable to form under these conditions. Decreasing the pH of the reaction resulted in the formation of heterometallic uranyl 2,6-PDC compounds that were previously described by Jayasinghe et al. and direct addition of 30% H2O2 to the solution led to the formation of 3.

elements.content: A major difference in the synthesis of compounds 2 and 3 is the ability to form peroxide crystals in the absence of light, which indicates that photoexcitation is not necessary for peroxide formation. Again, we can then turn to the solvent, or substrate, as a potential means to create peroxide in situ without a photoreaction. This follows that, again, autoxidation of the THF solvent could be the source of the peroxide. Assuming that the peroxide is formed at a steady rate, we could predict that 0.75 mg of O2 2– could be produced from autoxidation of THF alone. Considering that these crystals formed in 30% yield, then we would need a total of 0.48 mg of peroxide present, accounting for the formation of compound 3. Autoxidation pathways in the absence of U6+ or other metals also involves the formation of the THF hydroperoxide species, and the Raman spectra of the mother liquor after formation of 3 indicates that again this species is present in solution (Figure S10).

Autoxidation pathways in the absence of U6+ or other metals also involves the formation of the THF hydroperoxide species, and the Raman spectra of the mother liquor after formation of 3 indicates that again this species is present in solution (Figure S10).

elements.content: Again we attempted to identify degradation products in this system, but none were observed in the NMR or the Raman spectra. To further assess the importance of the THF as a substrate we also attempted the synthesis in the presence of ethyl ether, acetonitrile, and DMSO. In the presence of the ethyl ether and acetonitrile, crystals of UO2(C7H3NO4)­H2O formed and DMSO completely inhibited crystallization. We initially hypothesized that the ethyl ether would result in the formation of 3 because it is also a known peroxide former; however, changing the solvent likely altered the thermodynamics of this system to favor the formation of the pyridine dicarboxylate compound. As we previously reported, the room temperature synthesis of the UO2(C7H3NO4)­H2O compound occurs rapidly (less than 1 h), which would limit the peroxide concentration in solution and prohibit the formation of the uranyl peroxide dimers.

elements.content: We also cannot discount the importance of the bimetallic system because catalytic oxidation of THF could also potentially be enhanced by the presence of transition metals. Mallat and Baiker reviewed the use of ethers as sacrificial solvents and found that catalytic autoxidation of THF in the presence of molecular oxygen has been reported in the presence of salts or complexes of Fe, Co, Cu, Ni, Ag, Pt, Ru, Pd, Ir, Rh, Sr, and Ba. Shi undertook a detailed study of the catalytic oxidation THF in the presence Rh, Ru, Ir, and Pt catalysts and characterized the resulting products by GC–mass spectrometry and NMR spectroscopy. THF was found to oxidize to form butyrolactone as the major product along with minor amounts of lactol and 4-hydroxybutyraldehyde. While the Rh, Ru, and Pd catalyst exhibited enhanced lactone formation, IrCl­(CO)­(PPh3)2 could produce turnover values of 150. Li and Alper also reported the oxidation of cyclic ethers by CoCl2 in DME with a conversion rate of 87%. The major products of this reaction are a formate acetal (43%) and γ-butyrolacetone (34%). Li and Alpers proposed a mechanism that was based on initiation by cobalt-activated molecular oxygen, formation of a peroxide radical, and a termination step.

elements.content: In addition, the presence of transition metals in this system can interact with the peroxide generated in situ and further alter the formation of the product. Crystallization of 3 does not occur in the presence of Fe2+ and Cr3+, which is likely due to the presence of a redox active metal that can remove peroxide from the system in a mechanism similar to a Fenton reaction. This could also occur with Ni2+ or Co2+, but the overall redox reaction between the peroxide and the transition metal cation leads to a negative electrochemical potential with these two transition metals. Peroxide will also interact with protons to form water in acidic conditions (E red 0 = +1.77 V), thus minimizing the free peroxide available for the uranyl cation and inhibiting the formation of 3.

elements.content: The use of sacrificial solvents has been previously documented in the oxidation of organic molecules, but there is little literature precedent in the use of ethers to create solid peroxide phases. Peroxide solid are typically avoided due to the resulting chemical hazards, but in the case of uranyl peroxides, the stability of the compounds lowers the shock sensitivity of the material. Thus, the use of ethers and other peroxide-formers could be used as a new method to introduce peroxide into the system. Direct addition of 30% H2O2 to the system provides a spike in the concentration of free peroxide followed by a steady decrease with complexation and degradation in solution. Formation of hydroperoxide or peroxide radical through autoxidation or catalytic oxidation would control the peroxide levels and keep a steady concentration of peroxide throughout the crystallization process. This may be important in controlling the nature peroxide building units and creating novel materials because excess peroxide concentrations have previously been identified as a thermodynamic driving force toward the formation of uranyl peroxide nanoclusters.
elements.clean_text:
Potential Impacts of in Situ Peroxide Generation through Autoxidation of Organic Molecules

The use of sacrificial solvents has been previously documented in the oxidation of organic molecules, but there is little literature precedent in the use of ethers to create solid peroxide phases. Peroxide solid are typically avoided due to the resulting chemical hazards, but in the case of uranyl peroxides, the stability of the compounds lowers the shock sensitivity of the material. Thus, the use of ethers and other peroxide-formers could be used as a new method to introduce peroxide into the system. Direct addition of 30% H2O2 to the system provides a spike in the concentration of free peroxide followed by a steady decrease with complexation and degradation in solution. Formation of hydroperoxide or peroxide radical through autoxidation or catalytic oxidation would control the peroxide levels and keep a steady concentration of peroxide throughout the crystallization process. This may be important in controlling the nature peroxide building units and creating novel materials because excess peroxide concentrations have previously been identified as a thermodynamic driving force toward the formation of uranyl peroxide nanoclusters.

elements.content: Our study also suggests that the presence of organic matter, particularly those with ether, acetals, ketones, aldehydes, or some alcohol functional groups, could result in the formation of unexpected peroxide phases. This could be important for natural systems where photocatalytic degradation of humic and fulvic acids and microbial activity has been shown to produce peroxide. In addition, it should be a significant consideration for materials chemistry where there could be a reaction between organic materials and uranium solids, particularly in higher humidity environments. For example, epoxy, resins, or other adhesives used in material characterization may interact with uranium solids over time to produce peroxide phase like the one observed by Kirkegaard et al. Additional studies are necessary to further characterize the conditions that could lead to the formation of uranium peroxide phase within natural and experimental systems.

For example, epoxy, resins, or other adhesives used in material characterization may interact with uranium solids over time to produce peroxide phase like the one observed by Kirkegaard et al. Additional studies are necessary to further characterize the conditions that could lead to the formation of uranium peroxide phase within natural and experimental systems.

elements.content: The current study highlights the importance of the cosolvent identity in the formation of uranyl peroxide materials. THF is prone to autoxidation to form the hydroperoxide species and can be used to create novel peroxide phases. This was first demonstrated with the transformation of compound 1 and the uranyl peroxide dimer observed in 2. In this reaction, light was necessary to enhance the formation of peroxide and resulted in higher yields than expected for the resulting uranyl peroxide phase. Compound 3 was formed in the absence of light and is likely caused by pure autoxidation of the THF cosolvent in the presence of transition metals. In both cases, THF hydroperoxide was identified in the mother liquor after solid phase formation, confirming that THF was the source of the peroxide for the resulting compounds. This demonstrates the feasibility of using peroxide formers in the creation of new crystalline uranyl peroxide phases and the importance of these potential interactions whenever organic molecules are present in the system.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The current study highlights the importance of the cosolvent identity in the formation of uranyl peroxide materials. THF is prone to autoxidation to form the hydroperoxide species and can be used to create novel peroxide phases. This was first demonstrated with the transformation of compound 1 and the uranyl peroxide dimer observed in 2. In this reaction, light was necessary to enhance the formation of peroxide and resulted in higher yields than expected for the resulting uranyl peroxide phase. Compound 3 was formed in the absence of light and is likely caused by pure autoxidation of the THF cosolvent in the presence of transition metals. In both cases, THF hydroperoxide was identified in the mother liquor after solid phase formation, confirming that THF was the source of the peroxide for the resulting compounds. This demonstrates the feasibility of using peroxide formers in the creation of new crystalline uranyl peroxide phases and the importance of these potential interactions whenever organic molecules are present in the system.

cln_elements.content: A 0.2 M stock solution of 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate was generated by adding 0.334 g of the acid form of the ligand to 10.0 mL of water. Base (1.0 M LiOH) was added to deprotonate the carboxylate groups and promote dissolution. A 1.0 mL aliquot of the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate stock solution was combined with 1.0 mL of a 0.2 M uranyl nitrate (Flynn Scientific, Inc.) solution in a 20 mL glass scintillation vial. THF (2.0 mL) was also added to the vial, and then the solution was thoroughly mixed. A 1.0 mL aliquot of a 0.2 M iminodiacetic acid solution was subsequently added and the pH adjusted to 4.4 using pyridine. The solution was also layered with 5.0 mL of acetonitrile to aid in crystallization. After approximately 10 days, yellow acircular single crystals were formed with 75% yield based upon U. Crystals remaining in the mother liquor for a period of 1–2 months changed color from yellow to orange (2; (C5NH6)2[(UO2)2(μ-O2)­(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]·4H2O) and formed in similar yields. Initial syntheses were performed on the benchtop in the presence of ambient light (benchtop and sunlight), and a portion of subsequent experiments was stored in a drawer to minimize photochemical reactions.

Li(H2O)2(UO2)(C7H3NO4)(C4H5NO4)⋅2H2O (1)

A 0.2 M stock solution of 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate was generated by adding 0.334 g of the acid form of the ligand to 10.0 mL of water. Base (1.0 M LiOH) was added to deprotonate the carboxylate groups and promote dissolution. A 1.0 mL aliquot of the 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate stock solution was combined with 1.0 mL of a 0.2 M uranyl nitrate (Flynn Scientific, Inc.) solution in a 20 mL glass scintillation vial. THF (2.0 mL) was also added to the vial, and then the solution was thoroughly mixed. A 1.0 mL aliquot of a 0.2 M iminodiacetic acid solution was subsequently added and the pH adjusted to 4.4 using pyridine. The solution was also layered with 5.0 mL of acetonitrile to aid in crystallization. After approximately 10 days, yellow acircular single crystals were formed with 75% yield based upon U. Crystals remaining in the mother liquor for a period of 1-2 months changed color from yellow to orange (2; (C5NH6)2[(UO2)2(μ-O2)(H2O)2(C7NO4H3)2]⋅4H2O) and formed in similar yields. Initial syntheses were performed on the benchtop in the presence of ambient light (benchtop and sunlight), and a portion of subsequent experiments was stored in a drawer to minimize photochemical reactions.
